case_name: Messrs Alloy Steel Project v. Workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2128 of 1969 filed as appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2128 of 1969. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated July 19, 1969 of the Ninth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, Calcutta in case No. VIII-396 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal from Award dated July 19, 1969 of the Ninth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, Calcutta in case No. VIII-396 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2128 of 1969. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated July 19, 1969 of the Ninth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, Calcutta in case No. VIII-396 of 1968. K. Daphtarv. Santosh Chatterjee and D. N. Mukherjee, for the appellant.

facts.text: Alloy Steel Project started in the year 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Messrs Alloy Steel Project, is an undertaking owned, companytrolled and managed by a Government Company, viz., Messrs Hindustan Steel Ltd. Alloy Steel Project was started in the year 1961 and it went into production in the year 1964-65.

facts.text: Alloy Steel Project went into production in 1964-65.

anchor.surface_text: Alloy Steel Project was started in the year 1961 and it went into production in the year 1964-65. No profit was earned at least right up to the year 1967-68.

facts.text: No profit earned by Alloy Steel Project up to 1967-68.

anchor.surface_text: No profit was earned at least right up to the year 1967-68. The workmen, however, claimed bonus at the minimum rate prescribed under the Payment of Bonus Act No. 21 of 1965 hereinafter referred to as the Act in respect of the year 1965-1966

facts.text: Workmen claimed bonus for 1965-1966 at minimum rate under Payment of Bonus Act 1965, claiming Alloy Steel Project part of Hindustan Steel Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen, however, claimed bonus at the minimum rate prescribed under the Payment of Bonus Act No. 21 of 1965  hereinafter referred to as the Act  in respect of the year 1965- 1966 on the plea that this Alloy Steel Project was a part of the Hindustan Steel Ltd. and companyld number be treated as a new establishment for purposes of section 16 of the Act.

facts.text: Company resisted claim stating Alloy Steel Project separate establishment with separate balance-sheets and profit loss accounts.

anchor.surface_text: This claim of the workmen was resisted, by the Company on the plea that Alloy Steel Project was a separate establishment in respect of which separate balance-sheets and profit and loss accounts were maintained, so that numberbonus was payable until either this Project itself earned profits, or from the sixth accounting year following the year 1964-65 when this Project went into production.

facts.text: Dispute referred under Industrial Disputes Act 1947 to Ninth Industrial Tribunal West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute between the work-men and the Company. companyld number be resolved amicably and, companysequently, a reference was made under the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 which came up before the Ninth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal.

facts.text: Tribunal held Alloy Steel Project not separate but part of Hindustan Steel Ltd and directed 4% bonus payment.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that Alloy Steel Project companyld number be treated as a separate establishment because, under the Act, a Company is itself an establishment, so that all units of a Company like Hindustan Steel Ltd. will companystitute one establishment. Since this Project had number been earning any profits the Tribunal directed payment of bonus at the minimum rate of 4 per cent of wages prescribed by the Act.

facts.text: Company appealed to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by this award of the Tribunal, the Company has companye up in this appeal to this Court by special leave, though the name of the appellant is shown as Alloy Steel Project, because it was under this name that the reference was dealt with by the Tribunal.

facts.text: Hindustan Steel Ltd has establishments including Head Office, Rourkela Steel Plant, Bhilai Steel Plant, Durgapur Steel Plant, Coal Washeries Project, Bokaro Steel Project, Alloy Steel Project.

anchor.surface_text: The facts appearing on the record show that Hindustan Steel Ltd. has a number of. establishments. These include Alloy Steel Project besides the Head Office, Rourkela Steel Plant, Bhilai Steel Plant, Durgapur Steel Plant, Coal Washeries Project and Bokaro Steel Project.

facts.text: Separate balance-sheet and profit and loss accounts maintained for Alloy Steel Project.

anchor.surface_text: Alloy Steel Project was a separate establishment in respect of which separate balance-sheets and profit and loss accounts were maintained

facts.text: Annual reports for three years produced before Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is very clear evidence that, though the Company, Hindustan Steel Ltd., has a number of undertakings, Separate accounts are kept for each separate undertaking. The annual reports for three years were produced before the Tribunal.

facts.text: Separate balance-sheet prepared for each unit including Alloy Steel Project.

anchor.surface_text: They clearly indicate that separate balance-sheet was prepared for each unit and separate profit and loss account was worked out for each unit, except that, for the Head Office, though a separate balance-sheet was-prepared, the profit and loss was worked out on the basis of the companysolidated accounts.

facts.text: Evidence of Company's witness Umapada Chakraborty that separate accounts maintained.

anchor.surface_text: That accounts are separately maintained for each unit is number only established from the various annual reports filed before the Tribunal and the evidence of, the Companys witness Umapada Chakraborty

facts.text: Workmen's witness Suprakash Kanjilal admitted separate accounts and separate bonus calculations per unit.

anchor.surface_text: but is also admitted by Suprakash Kanjilal, the only witness examined on behalf of the workmen. The latter also admitted that separate bonus calculation is made in respect of each unit and bonus was declared separately in each unit.

facts.text: No bonus declared for Alloy Steel Project due to exemption claim under section 16.

anchor.surface_text: No bonus was, however, declared in respect of the Alloy Steel Project. That declaration was number made because of the claim that Alloy Steel Project was exempt from payment of bonus under section 16 of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Alloy Steel Project is separate establishment newly set up in 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, the Alloy Steel Project should have been treated as a separate establishment newly set up in the year 1961.

facts.text: No bonus payable to workmen of Alloy Steel Project for 1965-66 under section 16(1).

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, numberbonus was payable, to, the workmen of this undertaking for the year 1965-66 in view ,of the provisions of section 16 1  of the Act.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, Tribunal award set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed, the order of the Tribunal is set aside, and the reference of the dispute is answered accordingly.

facts.text: Hindustan Steel Ltd is a Government Company.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs Alloy Steel Project, is an undertaking owned, companytrolled and managed by a Government Company, viz., Messrs Hindustan Steel Ltd.

facts.text: Separate bonus declared in each unit of Hindustan Steel Ltd except Alloy Steel Project.

anchor.surface_text: The latter also admitted that separate bonus calculation is made in respect of each unit and bonus was declared separately in each unit. No bonus was, however, declared in respect of the Alloy Steel Project.

facts.text: Consolidated balance-sheet prepared for Hindustan Steel Ltd for Companies Act compliance.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has obviously gone wrong in ignoring the fact that separate balance sheets and profit and loss accounts are in fact maintained for each separate unit and the companysolidated accounts are prepared only for the purpose of companyplying with the requirements of the companypanies Act.

issues.text: whether this Alloy Steel Project could be held to be an establishment separate from Hindustan Steel Ltd., or it had to be treated as a part of the parent establishment, viz., Hindustan Steel Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: consider whether this Alloy Steel Project could be held to be an establishment separate from Hindustan Steel Ltd., or it had to be treated as a part of the parent establishment, viz., Hindustan Steel Ltd. In this approach, it is clear that the Tribunal committed an obvious error, as it ignored the indications which are manifest from the language used in the Act.

issues.text: the point raised has to be decided on the basis whether, under the proviso to section 3 the Alloy Steel Project is to be treated as a separate establishment, or is to be treated as part of the main establishment owned by Hindustan Steel Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: the point raised has to be decided on the basis whether, under the proviso to section 3 the Alloy Steel Project is to be treated as a separate establishment, or is to be treated as part of the main establishment owned by Hindustan Steel Ltd. Learned counsel for the respondent-workmen, however, advanced a new argument which was not put forward before the Tribunal.

issues.text: if an establishment of a Company consists of a number of departments, undertakings or branches, the principal part of section 3 will apply and all such departments, undertakings or branches must be treated as parts of one single establishment for purposes of computation of bonus under the Act, but the proviso to section 3 will not apply in such a case

anchor.surface_text: His submission was that, if an establishment of a Company consists of a number of departments, undertakings or branches, the principal part of section 3 will apply and all such departments, undertakings or branches must be treated as parts of one single establishment for purposes of computation of bonus under the Act, but the proviso to section 3 will not apply in such a case.

issues.text: Whether Alloy Steel Project is a newly set up establishment entitled to exemption from bonus under section 16 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: section 16 of the Act. Hindustan Steel Ltd. was itself an establishment which had been in existence for a long period and had been even earning profits, so that exemption could not be granted to this Company in respect of payment of bonus under s. 16 of the Act. This claim of the workmen was resisted, by the Company on the plea that Alloy Steel Project was a separate establishment

issues.text: an establishment cannot be identified with a company

anchor.surface_text: Obviously, therefore, an establishment cannot be identified with a company. It would be absurd to say that a company is owned, controlled or managed by a Government company or a corporation. Obviously, the word establishment is intended to indicate something different from a company as defined in the Companies Act.

arguments.claim: Establishment cannot be identified with a company as per s.2(15)(16)

anchor.surface_text: In section 2, sub-section  15  and  16 , establishments have been divided into two classes and their meaning has been defined... Obviously, the word establishment is intended to indicate something different from a company as defined in the Companies Act.

arguments.claim: Applicability under s.1(3) independent of s.3

anchor.surface_text: The Act has been made applicable to every factory and every other establishment in which twenty or more persons are employed... This applicability of the Act will be independent of the other provisions of the Act.

arguments.claim: Proviso to s.3 applies only if separate balance-sheet and P&L maintained

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 is as follows - Where an establishment consists of different departments or undertakings... Provided that where for any accounting year a separate balance-sheet and profit and loss account are prepared and maintained...

arguments.claim: Proviso s.3 does not apply to companies departments as s.6(d) deductions cannot be allocated to units

court_response_anchor.surface_text: circumstances do exist justifying such deductions. In the Third Schedule itself, the first deduction envisaged is dividend payable on preference shar

arguments.court_reasoning: Strange construction giving different meanings in same section; deductions only if applicable circumstances exist

arguments.claim: Separate accounts kept for each undertaking as per annual reports and witness evidence

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is very clear evidence that... The annual reports for three years were produced before the Tribunal. They clearly indicate that separate balance-sheet was prepared... admitted by Suprakash Kanjilal...

arguments.claim: Consolidated accounts only for Companies Act compliance not negating separate accounts

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has obviously gone wrong in ignoring the fact that separate balance sheets and profit and loss accounts are in fact maintained... consolidated accounts are prepared only for the purpose of complying with the requirements of the Companies Act.

arguments.claim: Alloy Steel Project qualifies as separate establishment under s.3 proviso

anchor.surface_text: the point raised has to be decided on the basis whether, under the proviso to section 3 the Alloy Steel Project is to be treated as a separate establishment...

arguments.claim: s.16(1) exemption applies to newly set up establishment

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  1  of section 16 grants exemption from payment of bonus to establishments newly set up... If the Alloy Steel Project is treated as an establishment newly set up for purposes of s. 16 1 , the exemption claimed would be fully justified.

arguments.claim: s.16(2) applies to new undertakings of existing establishments

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 2  of the Act makes it clear that the provisions of sub-section  1  are to apply even to new departments, undertakings or branches set up by existing establishments.

arguments.claim: Proviso to s.16(2) does not apply as no bonus paid on consolidated basis to all units

anchor.surface_text: The proviso to sub-s.  2  of section 16 also does not stand in the way... because there is no evidence at all that in any year... bonus was paid to the employees of all the units on the basis of consolidated profits...

holdings.text: The Tribunal committed an obvious error by ignoring the statutory language distinguishing 'establishment' from 'company'.

anchor.surface_text: consider whether this Alloy Steel Project could be held to be an establishment separate from Hindustan Steel Ltd., or it had to be treated as a part of the parent establishment, viz., Hindustan Steel Ltd. In this approach, it is clear that the Tribunal committed an obvious error, as it ignored the indications which are manifest from the language used in the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on definitions in s.2(15) and s.2(16) showing establishments owned/controlled by government companies, distinct from companies themselves.

holdings.text: An establishment cannot be identified with a company.

anchor.surface_text: Obviously, therefore, an establishment cannot be identified with a company. It would be absurd to say that a company is owned, controlled or managed by a Government company or a corporation. Obviously, the word establishment is intended to indicate something different from a company as defined in the Companies Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(15) and s.2(16) define public and private sector establishments separately from companies; ownership/control language implies distinction.

holdings.text: Under proviso to s.3, Alloy Steel Project is a separate establishment as separate balance-sheet and profit & loss accounts are maintained.

anchor.surface_text: the point raised has to be decided on the basis whether, under the proviso to section 3 the Alloy Steel Project is to be treated as a separate establishment, or is to be treated as part of the main establishment owned by Hindustan Steel Ltd. Learned counsel for the respondent-workmen, however, advanced a new argument which was not put forward before the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of annual reports and witness testimony confirms separate accounts for each unit, satisfying proviso conditions.

holdings.text: Proviso to s.3 applies to departments/undertakings of companies; no exception excluding companies.

anchor.surface_text: His submission was that, if an establishment of a Company consists of a number of departments, undertakings or branches, the principal part of section 3 will apply and all such departments, undertakings or branches must be treated as parts of one single establishment for purposes of computation of bonus under the Act, but the proviso to section 3 will not apply in such a case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejecting purposive argument based on s.6(d) deductions; same words in main section and proviso cannot have different meanings; deductions apply only if circumstances exist.

holdings.text: Separate balance-sheets and profit & loss accounts are maintained for each unit of Hindustan Steel Ltd., including Alloy Steel Project.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is very clear evidence that, though the Company, Hindustan Steel Ltd., has a number of undertakings, Separate accounts are kept for each separate undertaking. The annual reports for three years were produced before the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Annual reports, company witness Umapada Chakraborty, and admission by workmen witness Suprakash Kanjilal confirm separate accounts and bonus calculations per unit.

holdings.text: Consolidated accounts required by Companies Act do not negate separate unit accounts under Bonus Act s.3 proviso.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has obviously gone wrong in ignoring the fact that separate balance sheets and profit and loss accounts are in fact maintained for each separate unit and the consolidated accounts are prepared only for the purpose of complying with the requirements of the Companies Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Companies Act mandates consolidated statements but prohibits neither separate accounts nor their use for Bonus Act purposes.

holdings.text: Alloy Steel Project qualifies for exemption under s.16(1) as newly set up separate establishment.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, the Alloy Steel Project should have been treated as a separate establishment newly set up in the year 1961.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Set up 1961, production 1964-65, no profits till 1967-68; separate under s.3 proviso triggers s.16(1).

holdings.text: Provisions of s.16(1) apply to new undertakings of existing establishments per s.16(2); proviso to s.16(2) inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 (2) of the Act makes it clear that the provisions of sub-section (1) are to apply even to new departments, undertakings or branches set up by existing establishments. Provided that if an employer... on the basis of the consolidated profits computed in respect of all such departments or undertakings or branches...

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of bonus paid on consolidated basis to all units; Head Office exception justified but does not trigger proviso.

holdings.text: No bonus payable to workmen of Alloy Steel Project for 1965-66 under s.16(1).

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, no bonus was payable, to, the workmen of this undertaking for the year 1965-66 in view of the provisions of section 16 (1) of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: New establishment, within exemption period, no profits.

anchor.surface_text: consider whether this Alloy Steel Project could be held to be an establishment separate from Hindustan Steel Ltd., or it had to be treated as a part of the parent establishment, viz., Hindustan Steel Ltd. In this approach, it is clear that the Tribunal committed an obvious error, as it ignored the indications which are manifest from the language used in the Act.
The appeal is allowed, the order of the Tribunal is set aside, and the reference of the dispute is answered accordingly.

anchor.surface_text: Obviously, therefore, an establishment cannot be identified with a company. It would be absurd to say that a company is owned, controlled or managed by a Government company or a corporation. Obviously, the word establishment is intended to indicate something different from a company as defined in the Companies Act.
The appeal is allowed, the order of the Tribunal is set aside, and the reference of the dispute is answered accordingly.
